PREFACE. JT might scarcely appear necessary to furnish an explanation of the nature of this Synoptical Index to the “ English Cyclopaedia,” and of the mode of us'ng it for instant reference to any of the articles contained in the Twenty-two Volumes of that Work ; hut a few words of such explanation may not he wholly superfluous. “The Penny Cyclopaedia,” which was formed upon the principle of one alphabetical arrangement from the beginning to the conclusion of the work, contains, at the end of each letter, a list of the articles in that letter, with the pages of the volume in which they occur. There was convenience in this plan, although it was not absolutely necessary. Upon the completion of that work, the Indexes to all the Letters were printed off separately for private circulation. Everyone who possessed a copy of this separate Index felt how convenient it was to have it always at hand when wanting to refer to a particular article. Under {he arrangement of the “English Cyclopaedia,” in Four Divisions, such an Index, even if formed upon the common principle of one alphabetical order, with distinctive reference to the Volume of each Division in which the word occurs, would have been found exceedingly useful. The Conductor of the “ English Cyclopaedia,” having demised the plan of the present Synoptical Index, confided its execution to Mr. Eowman, the careful Sub-Editor of the original work. The reader will at once see that in the four columns which each page presents — of “ Geography,” “ Biography,” “Natural History,” “Arts and Sciences,” — the words in each Division are arranged in a parallel order, not only as regards the first letter of each word, hut of the second and third letters, according to the principle pursued in every Dictionary. With this Synoptical Index on his table, the student will most likely find at once the word he may seek according to his expectation of finding it in any one of the Four Divisions, but if it should not there be found, he has only to cast his eye across the other columns, and it is immediately presented to his view in its alphabetical parallelism. If the word which ho may seek should he a reference, he can immediately turn to the title referred to. In some cases the same word necessarily occurs in two Divisions : — thus, “ Cotton ” is found in thfe Division of “ Natural History,” Vol. II., column 172, and also in that of “Arts and Sciences,” Vol. III., column 249. IV PREFACE. The construction of tlio Index upon tliis plan lias been a work requiring great labour and minute care, both in the compiler and the printer. The Conductor of the “Cyclopaedia” trusts that its useful- ness will be generally appreciated; and that whilst the separation of the “Cyclopaedia” into four Divisions has its manifest advantages, the only objection to such an arrangement, namely, that it requires some exercise of thought to know in what Division to look for a word, is at once obviated by reference to the Synoptical Index.
